Content: But most of us aren’t just being, we’re rowing to get someplace, to some other shore, to a goal or some ideal place we want to reach. So where are we headed? What’s the other shore?
How do I experience the fact that, instead of having to get there for something, it’s right here and now? This is it; this is the other shore. In Buddhism we sometimes call it the Pure Land.
Source Title: The Dude and the Zen Master
The Dude and the Zen Master
Content: Off we go again, trying to get to the next other shore. And once we get there, the whole thing starts again. At first I think, Oh, finally I got somewhere; now I’m happy. But after a while I say, No, this isn’t it, I’ve got to get over there.
We think that what we’re looking for is somewhere over the rainbow, till we finally realize that it’s all just this.
Source Title: The Dude and the Zen Master

Source Title: The Dude and the Zen Master
Content: One in particular strikes me: Always maintain a joyful mind. Appreciate the struggles as opportunities to wake up.

Those dolls that are full of sand at the bottom. You push them and they oscillate quickly from side to side, and then come back to center. So as you practice, you’re filling up with sand. At first, even a weak force hits you and almost knocks you over, but you oscillate in big arcs till you come up standing again. As you practice more and more, it takes a stronger and stronger force to get you knocked over, and even then the oscillations aren’t so big, and before you know it you’re back to center.
Source Title: The Dude and the Zen Master
